title: What is 'nothing'? Does 'nothing' actually exist, or is there always 'something' even in 'nothing?' - Quora

response.answer_text: I am going to start to answer that question by first giving some background. I think this is an important question. A quick answer wouid be that empty suave is not empty. That there is small amount of energy in empty space. But since there is a lot of space, that small amount of energy is more than half if all that exists. Sometimes it is called Vacuum Energy. And Einstein’s Cosmological Constant was another approach to solving this problem. Einstein used an average amount from a typical region of space but it turns out the amount of Vacuum Energy can vary and vary by huge amounts from 10 to the negative 3 joules per cubic meter of so-called empty space to 10 to the 19th power joules per cubic meter at the center of a Black Hole. And the amount of Vacuum Energy can change over time in the same region of space. So the Cosmological Constant ( the figure used to represent the amount of energy in empty space) is not a constant. So that is a problem. Asking the question in a slightly different way, we can ask: “What is outside the physical universe?” A question that has been asked fir a few thousand years. So that is the short answer. I was just answering another question about Epigenetics and I was thinking some other topics related to your question. Here is the longer answer to your question: Does Epigenetics play a large or small role in brain development? I’m going to give an answer that is a bit unusual. One of the writers on Quora works for CRISPR which is a company that does gene sequencing. The guy is brilliant and he does this stuff for a living. And he self-published a book. He starts out talking about Epigenetics and he goes into great detail. But he never explains exactly how it works. He says we don’t know exactly how it works. He said it has quite a bit of influence but of course it’s difficult to say how much. It just seems like there is a lot that DNA does not explain. But it is difficult to quantify how much we don’t know. Then in the book he starts talking about other topics besides Epigenetcs - about philosophy and the general human condition - and he has absolutely no idea what he is talking about. It was as if he was just copying and pasting some almost random things he got off the internet. And what he got from the internet was not any kind of scientific research. It was just a hodgepodge of different things. Some from philosophy and some new age religion stuff and some of his own opinions. None of it made much sense. So he works for CRISPR and they take a more or less trial and error approach. They develop new medicines based on knowledge of genetics. But there is a lot they don’t understand. And I think you will find this same kind of drop off of knowledge in a lot of areas. I was reading that Einstein had been able to unify gravity and electromagnetism but other scientists didn’t believe him. They said things like: “Einstein refuses to abandon his old methods’. But the real problem is that there are flaws in the Standard Model which works very well but which is based on a Materialistic model of the universe. Einstein talked about De Sitter Space which is 7 sets of nested dimensions plus one Large Extra Dimension which encompasses all the other sets of dimensions and is infinite in many ways - which is very similar to the Christian model of the universe with the physical universe, heaven with multiple different levels and then God and the spiritual realm. So there have been many attempts to fill in this chasm of this dropoff of knowledge. Dark Matter, Dark Energy, String Theory are all attempts to fill in these mysteries. Catholic priests used to just say ‘It’s a mystery’ and I don’t know if we’ve progressed much beyond just saying ‘It’s a mystery”. It would seem that there is a lot outside the physical universe. There is God and the spiritual realm. And there is a lot in between the physical and the spiritual. Let’s say there are 8 sets of dimensions each with its own set of rules. We know the physical universe is complicated. It would seem that each of these other 8 sets of dimensions is complicated too, each with its own governing laws. It would seem that Epigenetics is another area where we begin to bump up against these other sets of dimensions and the mysteries of life and the universe.. The problem is we cannot study these other sets of dimensions in a scientific way . The energy just seems to jump around at random. Einstein had famously said: “God does not play dice.” If you look at the movement of Quarks, they look like popcorn popping, there doesn’t seem to be any detectable pattern. I would say it is because the source of the energy is partly and mostly outside the physical universe and involves multiple other sets of dimensions , each with differing rules, one expert on Gluons used the analogy of two people on roller skates, each carrying a basketball. There is also an observer and when the observer blinks, the two people on roller skates exchange basketballs. But there is a bit of a tussle and all we can see is the new position of the roller skates. Protons become neutrons billions of times a second. Their movement diesn’t make a lot of sense because its source is outside the physical universe and in multiple sets of other dimensions each with its own set of rules. A comment on scale: We began to run into these great gulfs of knowledge when we are dealing with what is very small in the physical universe. But some of the other dimensions do not have the same rules in terms of large and small and linear time. There are many things we do not know about the brain, about Quantum Physycs, about Epigenetics. Often we can find practical work-a-rounds sometimes by averaging the wavelike aspects of fundamental particles. But that does not mean we have a deep or complete understanding of what us going on. It continues to be a mystery. Thomas Edison, the great inventor, said we know one millionth of what is knowable. If we figureout a few pieces of the puzzle, that is progress but in some ways it barely makes a dent in what is unknown. We will always be living in the presence of mysteries. Peace.

Nothing means the non-existence of anything. That is not any thing but a negation of anything. Nothing is not any kind of actual thing but a concept or place holder for the concept of that which is opposotie of something. Since there cannot be a negation of things, therefore that is how the universe and everything in it has always existed, as something existing. That can be also shown other ways. Energy cannot be destroyed. Once it exists, or more correctly, since it exists, it always existed, or eternally. That also entails no beginning point for that existence otherwise, there would have been nothing before that point and then be considered as something similar to the big bang. An original time of its existence cannot be defined since that original time would again go back to a big bang or something like that. So the universe has to just exist, at all times. Since it has to exist then, there is no start. A start would be a point where before there was some thing. So existence is therefore a circular self sustaining aspect of everything that does exist. There is no way to get out of that circle that affirms existence. Therefore existence is eternal and applies to everything that does exist, including everything in the universe.

“Nothing” can be defined in various different ways, depending on the context. As a predicate, “nothing” is the absence of relevant meaning. “Nothing” is also widely used as pronoun subject. It then means the absence of some particular thing that one might expect to be present. In computing, to order processor to do nothing a “no-operation” order has to be issued. A control abstraction - a processor executing “no operation” infact behaves identically to a processor not following any directive. (Although one is computing and the other is not.) If nothing happened, was it really "nothing" that happened? Or was it rather something not happening. The term that is more unequivocally defined is Nothingness. It is general state of nonexistence, void of any thing. No thing can exist within nothingness. Existence is the ability to interact with physical or mental reality. General state of non-existence means no interactions. Although nothing and something seems to exclude eachother they can infact coincide. When you say “i am doing nothing” then you are really doing something. In there something can be included into nothing, the only requirement there is that nothing equates to not changing the outcomeI hope i was able to be some help rather than no help. If you have any more questions, the comments are open..

“Nothing” is exactly what it is - abscence of something. So “something” and “Nothing” are the same coin looked at from two perspectives. Both can’t exist side by side. The existence of one ceases the existence of the other. Simply put, nothing can’t give rise to something. It can be mathematically proven.Taken to the extreme about creation, darkness is the absence of light. When light comes, darkness disappears.

As I’ve said elsewhere, “nothing” is a word which signifies an intra-mental concept for which there is no extra-mental counterpart. That intra-mental concept is also often signified by the words: “sheer vacuity of all kinds of being whatsoever”. Needless to say, there cannot TRULY BE any such thing as a “sheer vacuity of all kinds of being whatsoever”, since it would then be a kind of being described as a “sheer vacuity of all kinds of being whatsoever”. In other words, it would be the self-contradictory equivalent of a “square circle”. A circle cannot be a square and still be a circle, and a “sheer vacuity of all kinds of being whatsoever” cannot be a kind of being and still be “a sheer vacuity of all kinds of being whatsoever.” Perhaps the best way to sum it up is to say that the human mind can play marvelous games with words.

Nothing is a description of what is (not) without creation. Since creation we cannot find nothing. Nothing is the absence of space and time. There are no dimensions and no potentials. Nothing is incomprehensible to the human mind because we live in a 4 dimensional something. The void, or vacuum, we talk about in physics is extraordinarily dynamic. It is teaming with fields and zero point energy. The vacuum is 4 dimensional.

This is more a question of semantics. “Nothing” is a word (a concept) which describes the absence of all things. A negation of existence, so to speak. If “nothing” included “something” it would be self-contradictory—an oxymoron—a logical fallacy. “Nothing” cannot be visualized normally. There are however, meditation and yoga techniques, so we’re told, the goal of which is to enable one to conceptualize and experience the actuality of the abstract construct. of nothing. I can’t verify this from experience. My attempts have resulted in forever reaching into a dizzying fog of infinite regression. (Thing is, “something” even a thought can’t approach “nothing” without obliterating it? I found this to be the same when trying to conceptualize the actuality of “infinity.”) Let nothing be nothing. . . T.

Nothing and Something are entangled aspects of Being. Or if you prefer Something is another word for Yang, Nothing is another word for Yin and Being is another word for Tao. A more accurate rendering however is that Being and Tao are empty undefined place holders for Possibility which alone is both something and nothing, which are Possibility’s most defining properties.

This looks like a very simple question, but in reality, it is a very complicated one. The best, and clearest, answer to it that I have found is a little book by Oxford scientist Frank Close: Frank Close, Nothing: A Very Short Introduction, Oxford University Press, 2009, 157 pages.

“Nothing” is just a word, a concept.It belongs to language(s), as does negation: English, maths, logic, set theory, information technology, … It DOES NOT belong to ontology: in reality it has no meaning whatsoever.For instance, “not cat” means something in set theory, but is void of meaning in the universe.
